occurrences.line_text: Cride out, Now now Sir knight, shew what ye bee,
Cride, Mercy mercy Sir vouchsafe to show
Then cride she out, Fye, fye, deformed wight,
Till Vna cride, O hold that heauie hand,
They heard a ruefull voice, that dearnly cride
Fiercely approching, to him lowdly cride,
But full of anger fiercely to him cride;
Of harmefull fowles about them fluttering, cride,
And cride to heauen, from humane helpe exild.
And now for helpe aloud in earnest cride.
That all the way full loud for aide did crie,
And on him catching hold, gan loud to crie
That he for dread of death gan loude to crie
Confusd with womens cries, and shouts of boyes,
Of his shrill cries him called to his aide.
Benumbes her cheekes: Then out aloud she cries,
When Witches wont do penance for their crime)
But that redoubled crime with vengeance new
Yet crime in her could neuer creature find,
And walketh forth without suspect of crime:
Puft vp with emptie wind, and fild with sinfull crime.
For well she wist, his crime could else be neuer cleare.
The tree of life, the crime of our first fathers fall.
With crime do not it couer, but disclose the same.
That had almost committed crime abhord,
Of anguish, rather then of crime hath beene,
And mortall vengeaunce ioyne to crime abhord?
Thus heaping crime on crime, and griefe on griefe,
Thus heaping crime on crime, and griefe on griefe,
Thenceforth she sought for helps, to cloke her crime withall.
How that thou art partaker of his crime:
Bablers of folly, and blazers of crime.
And gan abhorre her broods vnkindly crime,
To purge away the guilt of sinfull crime:
Whilest louing thou mayst loued be with equall crime.
My crime, (if crime it be) I will it reed.
My crime, (if crime it be) I will it reed.
Pure and vnspotted from all loathly crime,
The crime, which cursed Ate kindled earst,
Whom seeing fit, and with no crime defilde,
And crime to crime, by this thy cowheard feare.
And crime to crime, by this thy cowheard feare.
He gan to him obiect his haynous crime,
And now your crime with cruelty pursew.
Which hauing got, he vsed without crime
Albe they worthy blame, or cleare of crime:
The vgly vew of his deformed crimes,
And guilt of sinfull crimes cleane wash away,
When not for malice and contentious crimes,
And causelesse crimes continually to frame,
False crimes and facts, such as they neuer ment,
And lay on heauen the guilt of their owne crimes.
And many other crimes of foule defame
Of all those crimes, that he gainst her doth reare,
All hidden crimes, through all that realme he sent,
Which he had got abroad by purchase criminall.
That cleare she dide from blemish criminall;
Too rathe cut off by practise criminall
Her yellow lockes crisped, like golden wyre,
Drunke of the streame, as cleare as cristall glas;
As she sate carelesse by a cristall flood,
To the faire Critias his dearest Belamy.
Which to his Critias, shaded oft from sunne,
Like foolish flies about an hony crocke,
Doth meet a cruell craftie Crocodile,
And at her feete a Crocodile was rold,
One foote was set vppon the Crocodile,
With that the Crocodile, which sleeping lay
For that same Crocodile doth represent
For that same Crocodile Osyris is,
There also was king Croesus, that enhaunst
Yeeld me an hostry mongst the croking frogs,
In hope her to attaine by hooke or crooke,
The which her sire had scrap't by hooke and crooke;
Vnto the crooke t'abide the balefull stowre,
At last with creeping crooked pace forth came
And thrise three times had fild her crooked hornes,
With her two crooked handes she signes did make,
That with her crooked keele the land she strooke,
Whence he with crooked clawes so long did crall,
She old and crooked were, yet now of late,
As old and crooked and not good for ought.
By which few crooked sallowes grew in ranke:
Full weake and crooked creature seemed she,
And hop'd to reape the crop of all my care,
But that fiers fate did crop the blossome of his age.
Nor wicked beasts their tender buds did crop,
To crop his thousand heads, the which still new
Hath pruned from the natiue tree, and cropped quight.
That cropt the branches of the sient base,
And at one stroke cropt off her head with scorne,
Croscuts the liuer with internall smart,
That in his armour bare a croslet red.
But on his brest a bloudie Crosse he bore,
A bloudy crosse, and on his crauen crest
Curse on that Crosse (quoth then the Sarazin)
More greedy they of newes, fast towards him do crosse.
He bore a bloudie Crosse, that quartred all the field.
And that deare Crosse vpon your shield deuizd,
Who swelling sayles in Caspian sea doth crosse,
Her succourd eke the Champion of the bloudy Crosse.
Sad life worse then glad death: and greater crosse
Doth hast to crosse him by the nearest way,
Whose sight to her is greatest crosse, may fall,
By his owne sword, and by the crosse thereon,
Through vainely crossed shield he quite did pierce,
The Redcrosse knight toward him crossed fast,
And furie, to be crossed in his way,
All holding crosses in their hands on hye,
Who for some light displeasure, which him crost,
And crost the nearest way, by which he cast
The hot-spurre youth so scorning to be crost,
For fell despight, to be so sorely crost;
With which her winged speed is let and crost,
Kissing his hands, and crouching to the ground;
Do worship her, as Queene, with oliue girlond cround.
In her eternall trompe, with laurell girland cround.
The crowned often slaine, the slayer cround,
Beyond his croupe, the length of all her launce,
Nigh a speares length behind his crouper fell,
Decline her head, & touch her crouper with her crowne.
And ouerbore beyond his crouper quight,
Yet the stout Faerie mongst the middest crowd
And now the crowing Cocke, and now the Owle
Whilst freshest Flora her with Yuie girlond crownd.
That made her selfe a Queene, and crownd to be,
For euer with a flowring girlond crownd:
And crownd his coward crest with knightly stile;
Was of the Britons first crownd Soueraine:
They crownd the second Constantine with ioyous teares,
With gilden hornes, and flowry girlonds crownd,
And both were with one oliue garland crownd,
Before the spouse: that was Arion crownd;
The pleasaunt Bandon crownd with many a wood,
Crownd with a rosie girlond, that right well
And triple crowne set on her head full hye,
Aread Prince Arthur, crowne of Martiall band?
To natiue crowne and kingdome late ygoe:
Whose hoarie locks great grauitie did crowne,
Do not I kings create, and throw the crowne
In her owne hande the crowne she kept in store,
That in his crowne he counted her no haire,
Their aged Syre, thus eased of his crowne,
So to his crowne she him restor'd againe,
But Ã´ the greedy thirst of royall crowne,
Therefore he first wore crowne of gold for dignitie.
Next whom Morindus did the crowne sustaine,
Euen thrise eleuen descents the crowne retaynd,
Both in his armes, and crowne, and by that draught
Vsurpt the crowne, during their pupillage;
The crowne, which Vortiger did long detaine:
Did high aduaunce the crowne of Faery:
To crowne his golden lockes with honour dew;
Shall take the crowne, that was his fathers right,
And therewith crowne himselfe in th'others stead:
And crowne with martyrdome his sacred head.
Enioy the crowne, which they from Britons wonne
Th'vsurped crowne, as if that he were wood,
So shall the Briton bloud their crowne againe reclame.
Decline her head, & touch her crouper with her crowne.
And euery one did teare her girlond from her crowne.
So mischief fel vpon the meaners crowne;
And crowne your heades with heauenly coronall,
And crowne of heauenly praise with Saints aboue,
And of all Asie bore the soueraigne crowne,
That crowne true louers with immortall blis,
That is the crowne of knighthood, and the band
And steale away the crowne of their good name;
And heauie sway, that hard vnto his crowne
Strange was her tyre; for on her head a crowne
My mother Cambridge, whom as with a Crowne
And kept the crowne in which she should succeed.
Vppon her head she wore a Crowne of gold,
And Moone-like Mitre to a Crowne of gold,
Of thy sires Crowne, and from thy countrey deare.
And soueraine grace, with which her royall crowne
Seekes to subuert her Crowne and dignity,
Mercilla of her crowne, by her aspyred,
Had bene the keye of all that kingdomes crowne;
When her that Tyrant did of Crowne depriue;
And lost the crowne, which should my head by right adorne.
Saw a faire damzell, which did weare a crowne
Then was the oaken crowne by Pastorell
In the woods shade, which did the waters crowne,
Looke how the Crowne, which Ariadne wore
And euery head was crowned on his creast,
And crowned mitre rudely threw aside;
And crowned her twixt earnest and twixt game;
The crowned often slaine, the slayer cround,
But crowned with a garland of sweet Rosiere.
He bore a crowned litle Ermilin,
Might else haue with felicitie bene crowned:
Or that with Diademe hath euer crowned beene.
Crowned with girlonds of immortall baies,
She wore, with crownes and owches garnished,
And Nereus crownes with cups; his mates him pledg around.
That ioyes for crownes and kingdomes to contend;
And crownes and kingdomes to thee multiply.
With crownes and Diademes, & titles vaine,
All deckt with crownes, & chaynes, and girlands gay,
His cruell wounds with cruddy bloud congealed,
Whose clawes were newly dipt in cruddy blood,
And cruddy bloud enwallowed they found
Till crudled cold his corage gan assaile,
The crudled cold ran to her well of life,
Doth vanquish Crudor, and doth make
His name is Crudor, who through high disdaine
To Crudor, and desire him that he would
All this accord, to which he Crudor had compeld.
Faire Venus sonne, that with thy cruell dart
The cruell markes of many' a bloudy fielde;
Seemd in their song to scorne the cruell sky.
Shall I accuse the hidden cruell fate,
And through their iron sides with cruell spies
Hurled his beame so scorching cruell hot,
A cruell witch her cursed will to wreake,
How does he find in cruell hart to hate
And let her in; where of his cruell rage
And seizing cruell clawes on trembling brest,
Cruell reuenge, which he in hart did hyde,
His cruell facts he often would repent;
Full many mischiefes follow cruell VVrath;
Soone after comes the cruell Sarazin,
The cruell steele so greedily doth bight
Doth meet a cruell craftie Crocodile,
His cruell wounds with cruddy bloud congealed,
His cruell stepdame seeing what was donne,
The Pardale swift, and the Tigre cruell;
After his sportes, and cruell pastime donne,
That cruell word her tender hart so thrild,
Where foming wrath, their cruell tuskes they whet,
Their puissant force, and cruell rage attonce,
Sith cruell fates the carefull threeds vnfould,
Till that their cruell cursed enemy,
(I witnesse am) in many a cruell fight;
And bloudie mouthed with late cruell feast.
So downe he fell before the cruell beast,
With cruell malice and strong tyranny:
The sharpnesse of his cruell rending clawes;
Till with his cruell clawes he snatcht the wood,
That he could not endure so cruell cace,
The cruell wound enraged him so sore,
To plucke a bone, then from his cruell claw
So tossed was in fortunes cruell freakes;
As chained Beare, whom cruell dogs do bait,
Who prickt with courage kene, did cruell battell breath.
As gentle Hynd, whose sides with cruell steele
A cruell knife, that made a griesly wound,
His cruell sport, in stead of sorrow dew;
Out of her gored wound the cruell steele
Or cursed hand hath plaid this cruell part,
Accusing fortune, and too cruell fate,
Ah lucklesse babe, borne vnder cruell starre,
And cruell combat ioynd in middle space:
In cruell fight on lybicke Ocean wide,
Their deadly cruell discord to forbeare,
That downe they let their cruell weapons fall,
That same is Furor, cursed cruell wight,
She last should smart: with which cruell intent,
And with my heat kindled his cruell fyre;
Strong warres they make, and cruell battry bend
Full oft approu'd in many a cruell warre,
And stirre him vp to strife and cruell fight.
But rudely rag'd, and like a cruell Tygre far'd.
But yielded passage to his cruell knife.
Eftsoones his cruell hand Sir Guyon stayd,
With cruell purpose bent to wreake on him
Nor care of vow'd reuenge, and cruell fight,
Your cruell eyes endure so pitteous sight,
Such cruell game my scarmoges disarmes:
Debatefull strife, and cruell enmitie
Delighting all in armes and cruell warre,
That cursed man, that cruell feend of hell,
Cruell Reuenge, and rancorous Despight,
He ouer him did hold his cruell clawes,
That cursed weapon, when his cruell foes he queld.
Plonged continually of cruell Sprights,
When hauing laid his cruell bow away,
Which, those his cruell foes, that stand hereby,
Had reard himselfe againe to cruell fight,
And said, Caytiue, cursse on thy cruell hond,
Into his head, and cruell passage made
And euermore their cruell Capitaine
His cruell bow, wherewith he thousands hath dismayd.
From which young Hectors bloud by cruell Greekes was spilt.
And kindling coles of cruell enmitie,
And with most cruell hand him murdred pittilesse.
And cruell rancour dim'd his valorous
There she with them a cruell battell tride,
What warre so cruell, or what siege so sore,
To see a cruell fight doen by the Prince this day.
And couetous aspectes, all cruell enimies.
And that fourth band, which cruell battry bent,
All deadly daungerous, all cruell keene,
With which at him a cruell shaft he sent:
His speares default to mend with cruell blade;
Vile rancour to auoid, and cruell surquedrie.
Fierce battell against one, with cruell might and maine.
But for she saw him bent to cruell play,
Hath me subiected to loues cruell law:
Ne slake the furie of her cruell flame,
For fear the cruell Feends should thee vnwares deuowre.
The worlds reproch, the cruell victors scorne,
Why do thy cruell billowes beat so strong,
O do thy cruell wrath and spightfull wrong
With cruell threats, his passage through the ford to let.
A cruell shaft, headed with deadly ill,
Did th'other two their cruell vengeaunce blin,
For of that cruell wound he bled so sore,
And of his lucklesse lot and cruell loue thus plaind.
His cruell deedes and wicked wyles did spot:
Which with his cruell tuske him deadly cloyd:
His feeble hart wide launched with loues cruell wound.
And with huge strokes, and cruell battery
Which when his cruell enimy espyde,
Exceeding mone, and curst that cruell chaunce,
Yet there that cruell Queene auengeresse,
And afterwardes affray with cruell threat,
Before that angry Gods, and cruell skye
With zelous enuy of Greekes cruell fact,
Where he with cruell warre was entertaind
Soone as the cruell flames yslaked were,
And wreake your sorrow on your cruell foe,
That cruell element, which all things feare,
But cruell Mulciber would not obay
And cruell battels, which he whilome fought
Yet cruell Cupid, not herewith content,
Ne did he spare (so cruell was the Elfe)
Blindfold he was, and in his cruell fist
To cruell loue, and wrought their owne decayes:
But rather stird to cruell enmity,
(The worke of cruell hand) was to be seene,
Which seene, he much reioyced in his cruell mind.
Seeming transfixed with a cruell dart,
The cruell steele, which thrild her dying hart,
Through cruell knife that her deare heart did kerue.
With murdrous weapons arm'd to cruell fight,
Haue rays'd this cruell warre and outrage fell,
That cruell Atropos eftsoones vndid,
And cruell battell twixt themselues doe make,
Now made forget their former cruell mood,
Where when she saw that cruell war so ended,
There he amongst them cruell hauocke makes;
Shew'd all his bodie bare vnto the cruell dent.
Ah cruell hand, and thrise more cruell hart,
Ah cruell hand, and thrise more cruell hart,
And cruell sword out of his fingers slacke
Great God of loue, that with thy cruell darts,
And cruell spoyle, which he had spard, to stow:
As when Latonaes daughter cruell kynde,
With fell despight her cruell arrowes tynde
Or wrath of cruell wight on thee ywrake?
Be theirs, that haue so cruell thee forlorne;
Did closely with a cruell one consent,
From that his cruell foe, that him pursewd in sight.
Complayning of her cruell Paramoure,
This cruell conflict raised thereabout,
And on their foes did worke full cruell wracke:
Faint friends when they fall out, most cruell fomen bee.
And cruell blades yet steeming with whot bloud,
But they for nought their cruell hands would stay,
Mongst which the cause of their so cruell heat
And cruell shafts emblazond she beheld,
Ne can be cured of that cruell stroke
A cruell Tyrant had presumpteouslie
As withered weed through cruell winters tine,
Against that cruell Tyrant, which opprest
A cursed cruell Sarazin doth wonne,
With cruell chaufe their courages they whet,
With bright Chrysaor in his cruell hand,
Like as a ship, whom cruell tempest driues
Who being freed from Proteus cruell band
And there all day continew'd cruell fight,
But this the sword, which wrought those cruell stounds,
And bent against them selues their cruell hands.
To ioyne the combate with cruell intent;
But suffred cruell shipwracke by the way.
Meaning on him their cruell hands to lay,
The cause, they say, of this her cruell hate,
So cruell doale amongst her maides dauide,
As when a Beare hath seiz'd her cruell clawes
At sight thereof his cruell minded hart
No hand so cruell, nor no hart so hard,
And cruell heauens haue heapt an heauy fate;
Which when the cruell Amazon perceiued,
Restraines those sterne behests, and cruell doomes of his.
Nath'lesse that stroke so cruell passage found,
Crying to them their cruell hands to stay,
To all which cruell tyranny they say,
And drawne of cruell steedes, which he had fed
Did stay her cruell hand, ere she her raught,
The cruell Souldan, and with dreadfull fate
They doe his anger calme, and cruell vengeance stay.
A cruell carle, the which all strangers slew,
For ayde, against that cruell Tyrants theft,
And cruell enemies increased more;
Made cruell hauocke of the baser crew,
But Artegall seeing his cruell deed,
Which cruell outrage when as Artegall
His cruell hand, to smite him mortally,
What cruell hand thy wretched thraldome wrought,
There then began a fearefull cruell fray
Their cruell strokes and terrible affright;
To tell, what cruell hand hath thus arayd
Yet ceast he not for all that cruell wound,
And saued from his cruell villany.
Seeing his sharpe assault and cruell stoure
A cruell Beare, the which an infant bore
Gnashing his cruell teeth at him in vaine,
But to these happie fortunes, cruell Fate
Three mightie ones, and cruell minded eeke,
Without compassion of her cruell smarts:
Cruell Typhaon, whose tempestuous rage
With all the euill termes and cruell meane,
Whose cruell handling when that Squire beheld,
A saluage Bull, whose cruell hornes doe threat
Procur'd the Prince his cruell hand to stay,
By any skill out of his cruell hands;
Such was the conflict of those cruell Brigants there.
To stay their cruell hands from slaughter fell.
And cruell rigour her did much molest;
With cruell rage and dreadfull violence
Oft cursing th'heauens, that so cruell were
As if he would haue rent him with his cruell clawes.
And cruelly was slaine, that shall I euer mone.
With pretious bloud, which cruelly was spilt
Her golden lockes most cruelly she rent,
Thy cursed hand so cruelly haue swayd
Yet sith his fate so cruelly did fall,
Corineus conquered, and cruelly did slay.
Of that third troupe was cruelly assayd:
Cruelly they assayled that fift Fort,
Vpon the Bulwarkes cruelly did play,
And eke himselfe her cruelly exyld:
And slew him cruelly, ere any reskew came.
My Lady and my loue so cruelly to pen?
My Lady and my loue is cruelly pend
That erst all entrers wont so cruelly to scorch.
The mortall point most cruelly empight:
So cruelly these Knights stroue for that Ladies sake.
And afterwards themselues doth cruelly deuoure.
And there in chaynes her cruelly did bind,
Slew cruelly, and in the riuer drowned quight.
So cruelly did him pursew and chace,
And right and wrong most cruelly confound:
Or cruelly does wound, whom so she wils:
He sore doth wound, and bite, and cruelly torment.
Will full intent him cruelly to kill;
And murdred cruelly by a rebellious Mayd.
The more they him misust, and cruelly did beat.
Their Captaine there they cruelly found kild,
Without compassion cruelly he threw;
Full cruelly the Beast did rage and rore,
And gan renew her former cruelnesse:
Then the reproch of pride and cruelnesse.
A handsome stripling with great crueltee,
But rather y Scuith gogh, signe of sad crueltee.
And ioyd to make proofe of her crueltie
The pitteous pray of his fierce crueltie haue bin.
And breathes out wrath and hainous crueltie;
He had him seene, and felt the crueltie
For refuge from the Monsters crueltie,
Her noble bloud? the heauens such crueltie abhore.
He thought her to compell by crueltie and awe.
Yet still her crueltie increased more,
Such is the crueltie of womenkynd,
In crueltie and outrage she did pas,
And for more horror and more crueltie,
Had stayned with reprochfull crueltie,
The broken reliques of their former cruelty.
The fruitfull plaines, and with fell cruelty,
Who when he hath with spoiles and cruelty
Vpon the beast, that with great cruelty
No liuing creature could his cruelty asswage.
And all the world confound with cruelty,
How suffrest thou such shamefull cruelty,
The other cleped Cruelty by name:
They did much more their cruelty encrease;
Yet she it all did mar with cruelty and pride.
Their hardned hearts, enur'd to bloud and cruelty.
But now his cruelty so sore she drad,
And gan to blame him for such cruelty
Least if men you of cruelty accuse,
But cruelty and hardnesse from you chace,
Their cruelty, and him to punish more,
And now your crime with cruelty pursew.
A monstrous cruelty gainst course of kynde.
That life nigh crusht out of his panting brest:
And crusht his carkasse so against his brest,
That they haue crusht the Crab, and quite him borne
With hollow howling, and lamenting cry,
And cry, and curse, and raile, and rend her heare,
And with sharpe shrilling shriekes doe bootlesse cry,
At her so pitteous cry was much amoou'd
Ay wont to laugh, when them I heard to cry,
That like a Lyon he would cry and rore,
At last he was compeld to cry perforse,
Then gan the cursed wretch aloud to cry,
That all the fields resounded with the ruefull cry.
His feeble feet directed to the cry;
